taxon.name: earleaf acacia (en)
taxon.id_notes: Distinctive, curved leaf with several parallel midribs (the ‘leaf’ is actually a flattened rachis). A (large?) number of acacia species have a similar seedling form, so if there are two such species planted in the same area, care must be taken. Leaves alternate.
taxon.notes:
Assuming that the acacia in Haiti is this one, based on various
      online lists of planting projects. There are several similar
      species that are hard to tell apart as seedlings (e.g., Acacia
      mangium).

taxon.name: cashew (en), nwa o pom (ht)
taxon.id_notes:
Leaves alternate. Petiole short. In older seedlings, secondary
      veins almost perpendicular to midrib. Leaf sometimes reddish.
taxon.notes:
Native range probably does not include
    Haiti. Pre-domemestication species from NE Amazon Basin.

taxon.name: soursop (en), korosol (ht)
taxon.id_notes:
Leaves alternate, elliptic, with glossy upper
    surface. Secondary veins not visible.

taxon.name: breadfruit (en), labapen (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, tough, dark-green leaves. Youngest seedlings with serrated leaf margin, soon becoming deeply incised in older plants.
taxon.notes:
Not Artocarpus camansi Blanco, which is the wild relative
    of breadfruit.

It appears from iNaturalist and other resources (e.g.,
      https://phytokeys.pensoft.net/article/49602/ and
      doi:10.1007/s11676-018-0621-x) that Casuarina equisetifolia is
      the most common Casuarina in East Africa.  restoration: NOTE
      this can become an invasive under certain circumstances, and
      should probably not be encouraged.

taxon.name:
chèn (ht), Haitian catalpa (en), Jamaican oak (en), Spanish oak (en),
      yokewood (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite with long, thin peioles. Margin sometimes appearing sometimes coursely serrate but maybe just undulate. Leaves of young seedlings usually with pale yeallow variegation streaks on leaf.

taxon.name: sed (ht), sède (ht), Spanish cedar (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate, with 3-6 opposite leaflets. Secondary veins on leaflets faint, paler than lamina where visible, 5-8 pairs.

taxon.name: citrus (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole winged, obovately. Leaf blade obovate, dark green. Secondary veins obsure. Citrus (hybrid) species are difficult to tell apart. Use this genus-level class for most citrus IDs.

taxon.name: sour orange (en), zoranj si (ht)
taxon.id_notes:
May be impossible to differentiate from other
    citrus.
taxon.notes:
From the ORE website: "Wild sour oranges abound in most of the
      project areas." This variety may have long become
      widely naturalized.

taxon.name: key lime (en), citron (ht)
taxon.notes: A hybrid: Citrus micrantha × Citrus medica

taxon.name: kokoye (ht), coconut (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves emerge spirally from a hidden apex. Venation palmate.

taxon.notes: Most of these are placed here by inferrence “Cupressus in TZ”
Misidentified as a Prunus. Most likely a Rubiaceae.
taxon.id_notes: Small, opposite, coriaceous leaves with pale midrib. Longer twigs tend towards growing horizontally; then leaves are held in a single plane.

taxon.name: pacay (ht), ice-cream bean (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. In young seedlings, leaf consists of winged rachis and only two opposite leaflets.
taxon.notes:
So far (2021-03-23) just making assumption that the Inga in
    Haiti planting photos is this one.

taxon.name: mango (en, ht)
taxon.notes: Can be pruned multiple times for firewood
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole long. Leaves long, leathery, with secondary veins almost perpendicular to the midrib. Compare with cashew.

taxon.name: sapodilla (en), sapoti (ht)
taxon.native_range:
Southern Mexico, Central America and the
    Caribbean
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, elliptic, glossy above. Secondary veins inconspicuous. Compare with ANNOMURI.

taxon.name: Spanish lime (en), kenep (ht)
taxon.id_notes:
Rachis of leaves (in young plants?) can be winged and
    may be confused with Inga.

taxon.name: doliv (ht), moringa (en)
taxon.notes: Planted by Forest Nation in Haiti
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, bipinnate. Leaflets oval.

taxon.name: zaboka (ht), avocado (en)
taxon.id_notes:
Leaves alternate. Tending towards obovate, sometime
    reddish when young. Very generic tropical tree seedling leaves.
taxon.notes:
Karen: "Seedlings requires a lot of water the first 3
      years". Likely exotic in Haiti: first humans to Haiti ~1,200 AD,
      well after avocado was domesticated.

In Tanzania, the main restoration Pinus species appears to be
      Pinus patula Schltdl. & Cham., a native of Mexico.
      Most of the images are placed here by inferrence “Pinus in TZ”

taxon.name: bayawonn (ht)
taxon.native_range: Mexico, South America and the Caribbean

taxon.name: guava (en)
taxon.native_range: Caribbean, Central America and South America
taxon.id_notes: Leaves opposite. Secondary veins deeply sunken into leaf (from above).

taxon.name: tamarind (en), tamren (ht)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite on rachis, in 7-8 pairs, oblong in shape.

taxon.name: sea almond (en), zanmann (ht), ketapang (id)
taxon.id_notes:
Leaves alternate, obovate. Young seedlings still show
    the first pair of kidney-shaped leaves.

taxon.name: cacao (en)
taxon.id_notes: Leaves alternate. Petiole narrow, at an angle to plane of leaf, and swollen ‘knee’ at petiole apex. Leaves large, dark-green, with strongly curving secondary veins. Older plants show a ‘V’ pair of basal secondary veins, but these are less obvious in the smaller plants.
